results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

A short film which features the early stages of construction of the West Gate Bridge in Melbourne made more dramatic by being filmed from overhead, through a window of an airplane.

We see a Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) airplane in the film, one of Australia’s domestic airlines between its inception in 1946 and its merger with Qantas in September 1992.

There are also scenes of life at home in Heathmont in Melbourne’s southeast, including family members modelling dresses, menswear and tennis gear for the camera.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film. Note that the film goes unexpectedly dark for several seconds at 00:2:12:00.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 landing gear of a plane filmed through a window during takeoff
00:00:13:00 landing gear retracting as plane rises into the air
00:00:28:00 residential areas in Melbourne (likely to be Essendon) filmed from overhead
00:00:35:00 views of each end of the Westgate Bridge during construction
00:01:17:00 a container ship in Port Phillip Bay
00:01:40:00 plane landing gear being lowered
00:01:54:00 passengers alighting from a TAA airplane on the tarmac (likely a Lockheed Electra Mk2 Aircraft)
00:02:44:00 women of the family modelling dresses walking toward the camera
00:03:25:00 showing the pets in the garden
00:04:23:00 the camera pans out over the residential fringe, capturing a view of the Dandenong Ranges in the distance
00:05:24:00 a view of the front of the Heathmont family home
00:05:31:00 women of the family modelling bathing suits of the day walking from and toward the camera
00:05:56:00 a classic car model from the 1940s

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 3. Moomba 1964] [excerpt]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is an excerpt from Reel 3 showing Melbourne’s Moomba street parade 1964, featuring colourful parade floats, marching girls, musicians and popular personalities of the day. The floats are assembled at the top of Swanston St before they head off for the big parade.

results.title: [Chinese theatre]
results.creator_credit: Victoria Mercanton, Marc Maurette, Theodora Olembert, Procinex and Triangle Productions
results.brief_description: Episodes are performed by a Peking theatrical company which portray some Chinese legends and symbols; “Trouble in Heaven”, “The Legend of the King and the monkeys”, “The Greatness of love”, “Story of the beautiful white fairy”, “Where the roads meet”, “A Case of mistaken identity” and finally “Autumn River”.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1974
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This films shows time with First Nations people of New Guinea, a wedding in Goroka, a wedding in Sydney, and a royal visit of Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne to Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:19:00 ancestral house of worship – “House of Tambaran” – seems to be specific to East Sepik group in PNG
00:00:36:00 children in traditional local dress with elders, gathered and building houses
00:01:07:00 playing wooden instruments, similar to flute and pipes
00:01:30:00 stunning views of mountain scene
00:02:20:00 driving through Australian bush, then Sydney beaches
00:07:48:00 toddler in wading pool in yard, Goroka
00:10:04:00 wedding in Goroka
00:12:24:00 carnival or fair, possibly the Sydney Royal Easter Show
00:13:17:00 footage of Sydney Opera House, Circular Quay and a ferry cruise on the Sydney Harbour
00:14:55:00 views of Bondi or Bronte
00:15:38:00 friends gather in Sydney for a wedding
00:16:31:00 back to PNG, family and friends
00:17:42:00 gathering in town in traditional dress to welcome Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip and Princess Anne
00:19:49:00 Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Princess Anne, Captain Phillip, Barry Holloway MP in back of truck being driven through crowds of people, Goroka

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie is shot in New Guinea. It includes scenic views over the bay (possibly Mapang), traditional dress, dance and reenactments, and a gathering and BBQ at the Faith Mission in Lufa.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:36:00 scenic view over the bay in Port Moresby, car in shot has ‘Mapang Missionary Home’ written on side
00:04:34:00 gathering of people wearing traditional dress from various districts
00:06:25:00 celebrations begin with parachuters landing from above into middle of football field
00:07:14:00 in traditional dress, people gather, reenactment of fighting, and dancing
00:10:33:00 ‘Faith Mission Hairo’ sign in Lufa, a BBQ and gathering of people including Evelyn Sinclair
00:12:33:00 another gathering at S.I.L. (Summer Institute for Linguistics) in Ukarumpa

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This very short film contains footage of mountains on the way to Lae, New Guinea. It relates to reel B2003518.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 side of the car says ‘I like Swipe’: may refer to “Swipe” cleaning products
00:00:18:00 stunning views of mountains
00:01:06:00 war memorial or monument

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This home movie shows the filmmaker and his wife travelling around England in a small yellow mini. They begin in London and travel across England to Stonehenge, up through the south of Scotland up to Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park, back to Edinburgh and end up in Blackpool.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:02:47:00 changing of the Guard
00:05:23:00 Stonehenge – brief look at Stonehenge
00:05:34:00 Stratford-Upon-Avon Cricket Club sign, walking through gardens and a spot of cricket
00:06:58:00 Shakespeare’s Birthplace Trust
00:09:17:00 road trip sign to Penrith, Carlisle and Kendal
00:10:17:00 Fferry trip – Windemere ferry, ’The Ferry House Windemere Laboratory of the Freshwater Biological Association Private Gardens’
00:13:15:00 Loch Lomond Sailings Ltd
00:14:42:00 the Elizabethan Inn – filmmaker and wife meet up with three other women at the inn
00:15:39:00 Tormore Distillery with friends – Long John Scotch Whiskey
00:16:56:00 father and two young girls feeding ducks at a lake
00:17:41:00 Roths Glen Hotel – mini donkeys and friends
00:19:11:00 sign to Pitlochry
00:19:45:00 castle or Military Fort in Edinburgh, guards in kilts
00:20:17:00 cemetery for soldier dogs
00:21:14:00 Blackpool

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This is a very short film, featuring graduating students posing with certificates from Goroka Technical College, Margot Gillian, Chapel and opening of the Development Bank at Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:01:07:00 opening of Development Bank, Goroka
00:01:43:00 local group perform ceremony in traditional dress to celebrate opening of bank
00:02:11:00 amazing mouth pieces worn by First Peoples as part of their ceremonial dress, procession

results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a cruise from Sydney Harbour to possibly New Caledonia, Fiji and New Zealand, including scenic views, time with friends’ son and off the cruise ship.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 leaving Sydney Harbour in cruise ship; views of the Opera House and the Harbour
00:01:36:00 views from lookout wth friends, looking over a small city
00:04:27:00 a day trip from cruise to island, maybe New Caledonia, due to circular style of grass hut
00:05:26:00 ring volleyball game on cruise ship
00:06:43:00 views from cruise ship coming into port at Nadi, Fiji
00:08:26:00 filmmaker’s wife Evelyn with local family, and swimming at the beach
00:10:08:00 cruise ship coming into port, marching band farewells/welcomes passengers
00:11:50:00 Rainbow Springs sign, Rotorua, NZ
00:12:06:00 trout farm at Rainbow Springs Nature Park
00:13:42:00 hot springs in New Zealand
0014:27:00 cruise ship coming back into Sydney harbour, views of cliffs surrounding Sydney Harbour

group.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movie Collection]
group.headline_credit: Australia, Papua New Guinea, United Kingdom and United States, 1960-1979
group.material_description: 9 x large & 5 x small Super-8mm reels of home movie footage, labelled O/S & Pacific Island cruises, New Guinea, Ireland, "Messiah" etc
